node.title: $25k event proposed to spur Invercargill City Council participation
node.description: The proposal follows comments from a community panel that more needed to be done to encourage a more diverse and representative council.

node.title: 'The fair thing to do' - Govt to increase payments to struggling families
node.description: Almost 350,000 families will get an extra $20 a week from April next year, lifting 6000 more children out of poverty, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says.

node.title: Living wage guaranteed to public service contractors
node.description: Cleaners, caterers, security guards and other contractors for core public service departments and agencies will be paid at least the living wage of $22.75 an hour, the government says.

node.title: Eight killed after crowd surge at US music festival
node.description: At least eight people have died and scores of people have been hurt after a crowd surge on the opening night of a music festival in Houston, Texas.

node.title: Dire Straits member John Illsley: 'We weren't part of a trend and never have been'
node.description: As punk music took hold, Dire Straits enjoyed huge success with a style of rock all their own which found favour worldwide including in Aotearoa, founding member John Illsley says. Audio

node.title: Scores dead after tanker explosion in Sierra Leone
node.description: The accident happened after the tanker collided with another vehicle in the nation's capital, Freetown.

node.title: 'Long overdue': Biden hails passing of infrastructure bill as monumental step
node.description: The long-delayed $US1 trillion spending package is a major domestic win for the president.

node.title: 'Feminist perspective' promised as author begins new Bond trilogy
node.description: Author Kim Sherwood is to write a new trilogy of James Bond books, becoming the first female author in the series of spy novels created by Ian Fleming.

node.title: Well-preserved ancient slave room unearthed in Pompeii
node.description: Archaeologists have discovered a room of objects among the buried remains of ancient Pompeii, and say its contents shed light on the lives of slaves.

node.title: Criminal probe opened into stampede at rap concert that left 8 dead
node.description: A criminal investigation has been opened after a stampede during rap star Travis Scott's Astroworld music festival in Houston killed at least eight people

node.title: Prince Charles to visit Barbados to mark republic's birth
node.description: Prince Charles will travel to Barbados to mark the Caribbean island's transition to a republic which entails the removal of Queen Elizabeth as head of state.

node.title: No sign of shark attack victim as search continues
node.description: There is still no sign of a man believed to have been taken by a shark at Port Beach in Western Australia on Saturday morning.

node.title: Sydney to further ease Covid-19 curbs as vaccinations pick up
node.description: Sydney will further ease social distancing curbs tomorrow, a month after emerging from a coronavirus lockdown that lasted nearly 100 days, as close to 90 percent of people have got both doses of…

node.title: Attempted assassination against Iraq's prime minister fails
node.description: An explosive-laden drone has targeted the Iraqi prime minister's residence in what the country's military say was an unsuccessful assassination attempt.

node.title: Founding member of band UB40 dies at 64
node.description: British vocalist and founding member of UB40 Terence Wilson, better known by his stage name Astro, has died aged 64. Video

node.title: Rittenhouse said he 'had to shoot' after opening fire, jury hears
node.description: Shortly after opening fire during racial justice protests in Wisconsin in 2020, teenager Kyle Rittenhouse told a witness in his murder trial that he had no choice but to use his semi-automatic rifle…

node.title: Hamilton train to run to central Auckland when service resumes
node.description: The Hamilton to Auckland commuter train will travel direct into central Auckland once the service resumes.

node.title: AstraZeneca vaccine will soon be available for some - Bloomfield
node.description: The Director-General of Health says for the "few hundred people" in NZ who could not have the Pfizer vaccine "for medical reasons" there was the option of AstraZeneca.

node.title: Company director jailed for sharing child sex abuse material
node.description: A Hamilton man has been jailed for sharing child sexual abuse material online.

node.title: Covid-19: 147 new community cases today, another death in home isolation
node.description: There have been 147 new cases of Covid-19 reported in the community today - including 14 in Waikato - with another death of someone with Covid-19 who was isolating at home.

node.title: DOC to stop waiving concession fees for tourism operators
node.description: Tourism leaders are warning businesses may fold after the Department of Conservation announced it will stop waiving concession fees.

node.title: Person with Covid visited Taranaki at start of November, DHB believes
node.description: Recent wastewater results suggest a Covid-infectious person was in Taranaki from the start of November, the region's top doctor says.

node.title: School reeling after three staff die in crash
node.description: The principal of a New Plymouth school which has lost three staff members in a horror crash in Horowhenua says the community is reeling at the news.

node.title: School's (almost) back: 'Anything we can do to get them back there safely is fine with us'
node.description: It's been three months since most Auckland students have been in the classroom, one parent says learning from home hasn't been easy for anyone.

node.title: Two men, one woman arrested over West Auckland murder
node.description: Three people have been arrested and charged with murder for the killing of Robert Hart in the Auckland suburb of New Lynn last week.

node.title: Democrats’ Divide: Should Obama-Era Economic Ideas Prevail in 2021?
node.description: A more traditional view is competing against a newer approach that has become mainstream among economists.

node.title: C.D.C. Recommends Covid Booster Shots for Millions of Americans
node.description: Recipients of the Moderna and the J.&J. vaccines may receive extra doses. The agency also embraced a “mix-and-match” strategy.

node.title: Men Are Caregivers, Too, in Democrats’ Plan
node.description: Compared with its peers, the U.S. has little in the way of family policy, but where it exists, it has mostly treated men and women the same. The Democrats’ plan would cement that.

node.title: Proposed Tax on Billionaires Raises Question: What’s Income?
node.description: Democrats are homing in on unrealized capital gains raises as a way to help fund their social spending bill.

node.title: This May Be Democrats’ Best Chance to Lower Drug Prices
node.description: For patients with certain cancers, out-of-pocket spending can exceed $15,000 a year. Legislation could take aim at prices and the amounts Medicare patients are charged.

node.title: In the Biden Bill, the Billionaires Beat the Working Rich
node.description: One by one, tax proposals that would have slowed dynastic wealth have been tossed from the agreement.

node.title: Widespread Coronavirus Infection Found in Iowa Deer, New Study Says
node.description: The analysis by Penn State and Iowa researchers strongly indicates that deer are getting the virus from humans, worrying experts about a deep wild reservoir for the virus.

node.title: Margaret York, an L.A.P.D. Model for ‘Cagney & Lacey,’ Dies at 80
node.description: She became the police force’s highest ranking woman after she and a detective partner inspired a TV series fighting crime in the streets and sexism in the ranks.

node.title: Tom Matte, Emergency Quarterback for Baltimore Colts, Dies at 82
node.description: A gritty running back, he was enlisted to replace Johnny Unitas and his backup as quarterback in critical games in 1965. He wore a wristband to remember the plays.

node.title: Nelson Freire, Piano Virtuoso of Warmth and Finesse, Dies at 77
node.description: Hailing from Brazil as one of the great pianists of the last half of the 20th century, he recalled masters of the first half in his virtuosity. But he shunned the limelight.

node.title: Pamela McCorduck, Historian of Artificial Intelligence, Dies at 80
node.description: She interviewed many of the scientists who were at the heart of the field through the end of the 1970s, and she compiled a groundbreaking history of its early years.

node.title: Ivy Nicholson, Model and Warhol Factory Star, Dies at 88
node.description: She blazed through 1950s Europe as a top fashion model and then became a part of the 1960s Warhol crowd in New York before falling on hard times.

node.title: Camille Saviola, ‘Deep Space Nine’ and Stage Actor, Dies at 71
node.description: She was known for her comic work in cabarets, for her performance in the musical “Nine” on Broadway and for her role in a “Star Trek” spinoff.

node.title: Ronnie Wilson, Founder of the Gap Band, Dies at 73
node.description: After beginning his career as a teenager, he joined with his two younger brothers to record R&B hits like “You Dropped a Bomb on Me” and “Outstanding.”

node.title: Aaron Feuerstein, Mill Owner Who Refused to Leave, Dies at 95
node.description: After a fire devastated his Massachusetts factory in 1995, he kept paying his employees and spent hundreds of millions to rebuild.

node.title: JoAnna Cameron, an Early Female Superhero on TV, Is Dead at 73
node.description: In addition to achieving Saturday morning fame as Isis, she was said to have appeared in more national television commercials than anyone in advertising history.

node.title: Marília Mendonça, Brazilian Pop Singer, Dies in Plane Crash at 26
node.description: Ms. Mendonça, who was a social media sensation with millions of followers, was iconic in a type of Brazilian country music called sertanejo.

node.title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
node.description: This week’s homes are a five-bedroom in Lloyd Neck, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Greenwich, Conn.

node.title: Living on the Edge, Literally: Homes Perched on Cliffs
node.description: It takes some creative engineering — and a bit of daredevil spirit — to build a house that is truly waterside.

node.title: The Growing Appeal of a House on the Lake
node.description: Here are four up-and-coming destinations for buyers who want access to water sports in their front yard.

node.title: Don’t Throw Away That Ancient Pink Toilet. Someone Out There Wants It.
node.description: Retro-minded homeowners are driving across the country and paying thousands of dollars to restore or recreate a vintage bathroom or kitchen.

node.title: Glenn Ligon
node.description: For over 30 years, the artist has been making work that speaks to American history — ambiguous, open-ended, existentially observant. At a time in which the fundamentals of fact and fiction are being questioned, his art captures the truth of a culture in decline.

node.title: Juliette Binoche
node.description: Quite possibly the most captivating — and elusive — performer of our time, the actress has built a career around a seemingly endless exploration of what it means to be human.

node.title: A New Wellness Brand That Harnesses the Power of the Garden
node.description: During the pandemic, longtime creative director Scott Formby found respite, and inspiration for a new venture, in his own lushly planted backyard.

node.title: The Visionary Community of the Harlem Y.M.C.A.
node.description: In the early 20th century, the building became a meeting place for many of the writers, artists, actors and activists who defined a new and vibrant Black culture.

node.title: Yvonne Orji Reflects on the End of ‘Insecure,’ and Tells T a Joke
node.description: The comedian looks back on her years working on the career-defining show and demonstrates her trademark wit.

node.title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
node.description: Platforms on parade, a fermenter’s adventures — and more.

node.title: How Corruption Ruined Lebanon
node.description: The deadly port blast, the triple-digit inflation, the energy shortages — Lebanon’s many crises have a shared root: misrule by a self-dealing elite.

node.title: Kenneth Branagh Is Finally Processing His Childhood Trauma
node.description: “I hesitate to use the word … a cardinal sin for my parents was to be suggesting that anything you’d been through was worthy of categorizing in such a way.”

node.title: How to Keep a Journal
node.description: Try to establish a routine. Sometimes it helps to give yourself a prompt.

node.title: How Scribbling in the Margins Transformed My Reading
node.description: This grounding practice changed me from a passive reader into a thinker among other thinkers.

node.title: Should I Tell a Facebook Friend I Had an Affair With Her Partner?
node.description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on responding to infidelity.

node.title: Inside the Unraveling of American Zionism
node.description: How a new generation of Jewish leaders began to rethink their support for Israel.

node.title: The Strange Effects of Putting an Ordinary Woman Into Glamorous Images
node.description: Celeste Barber’s Instagram elegantly prompts us to consider why we put so much stock in unrealistic imagery.

node.title: An Almanac of Covid Dreams
node.description: At the height of the pandemic in 2020, thousands of people shared their Covid dreams on Twitter, many of them under the hashtag #coronadreams. Here is a small selection.

node.title: Judge John Hodgman on the Uncapped Water Bottle
node.description: A “clumsy fellow” demands his partner be more conscientious with her hydration.

node.title: Poem: We Feel Now a Largeness Coming On
node.description: Tracy K. Smith reminds us how “being called all manner of things / from the dictionary of shame,” we do learn to become something mighty.

node.title: Will World-Class Architecture Bring Civic Pride Back to Memphis?
node.description: Spurred by Herzog & de Meuron’s new art museum and a rethought waterfront park by Studio Gang, city leaders turn to design to make a downtown for “everyone.”

node.title: William Conway, Who Reimagined America’s Zoos, Is Dead at 91
node.description: He sought to conserve wildlife and encouraged zoos to exhibit animals in their natural habitats. But he lost a battle to rename the Bronx Zoo.

node.title: International travelers eagerly await reunions with their loved ones as the U.S. travel changes near.
node.description: On Monday, travelers from many other countries who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus will be allowed to enter the United States.

node.title: ‘Her touch, her kiss’: A couple reunites as the U.S. reopens to many vaccinated travelers.
node.description: Romantic partners and families rejoiced as they met in airports after long months of separation because of pandemic travel restrictions.

node.title: What to Cook This Week
node.description: With fall upon us in earnest, warm up with lamb meatballs and spiced tomato sauce.

node.title: Are You Anxious, Avoidant or Secure?
node.description: Over a decade after its publication, one book on dating has people firmly in its grip.

node.title: What a $50 Million Donation Did for One H.B.C.U.
node.description: At Prairie View A&M, one of the historically Black colleges and universities where MacKenzie Scott donated millions, the mood is cautious optimism.

node.title: Un desconocido parecía mi gemelo. Ese fue solo el comienzo
node.description: Un correo electrónico reveló un viejo secreto de mi familia, luego tuve que aprender a vivir con eso.

node.title: Jil Sander Ski Wear, Coming to a City Block Near You
node.description: Fashion’s reigning minimalists collaborate with Arc’teryx, the outerwear brand favored by hikers and hypebeasts.

node.title: What We Learned From Week 9 in the N.F.L.
node.description: Baker Mayfield took control of a Browns team that looked ready to collapse. The Packers got their first long look at Jordan Love, and Dak Prescott and Josh Allen struggled in shocking upsets.

node.title: What Do You Want to Know About Kids and Vaccines?
node.description: The Times is hosting a live chat with a pediatric infectious disease specialist and two reporters about the coronavirus vaccine and children. We’d like to hear your questions.

node.title: Congress Is Investigating McKinsey Over Its Role in the Opioid Crisis
node.description: A House committee has requested documents related to the firm’s advice to drug makers and potential conflicts of interest with the F.D.A.

node.title: Michael Rutter, Pioneering Child Psychiatrist, Is Dead at 88
node.description: His wide-ranging research helped transform his field, a colleague said, by “insisting on using data to drive thinking about diagnosis and treatment.”

node.title: Stephen Karpiak, Pathbreaking H.I.V. Researcher, Dies at 74
node.description: His work helped change people’s attitude toward older people living with the virus that causes AIDS.

node.title: Rabbi Earl A. Grollman, 96, Dies; Sought to Demystify Death and Grief
node.description: He wrote prolifically about grief, counseled the bereaved after 9/11 and the Oklahoma City bombing and paid particular attention to children. “Grief is the price we pay for love,” he’d say.

node.title: To Build the Metaverse, Meta First Wants to Build Stores
node.description: The social networking company has discussed opening physical stores to showcase its virtual reality and augmented reality devices.

node.title: Crypto Is Cool. Now Get on the Yacht.
node.description: NFT.NYC, a gathering for nonfungible token enthusiasts, offered a taste of a crypto-filled future.

node.title: Google Temps Fought Loss of Pandemic Bonus. And Won.
node.description: When a Google staffing agency reneged on a promise to pay an attendance bonus, temps who are part of the company’s union organized and forced it to backtrack.

node.title: Rivian prices its I.P.O., valuing the electric-vehicle maker at nearly $70 billion.
node.description: The company, backed by Amazon and Ford, has delivered only 156 trucks so far, but its market worth approaches that of Ford.

node.title: Protesters Gather Outside Missouri Fraternity After University Suspends Greek Activities
node.description: "Hazing has gone on for too long, and it shouldn't take someone almost dying for the university to do something about it," student Olivia Sommer said.

node.title: Teacher on Leave After 'War Hooping, Tomahawk Chopping' Dance in Math Class Sparks Outrage
node.description: The video was filmed by a Native American student who reportedly "felt that violence was being committed against him."

node.title: Mom Sparks Backlash for Telling Child It's 'Her Own Fault' She Missed Out on Dream College
node.description: The Redditor reportedly told her daughter that "every assignment [she] never turned in is a dollar [she] p**sed away."

node.title: Ohio High School Cancels Performance of 'She Kills Monsters' Over Implied Gay Character
node.description: The play is among the most popular modern productions for high schools and the version planned had been retooled for young audiences.

node.title: Lawsuit Alleges Professor Was Fired for Criticizing Mike Pence: 'Little Demon Mouth'
node.description: Lora Burnett alleges her termination violated her First Amendment rights because it came after she posted on Twitter that Pence was a "scumbag."

node.title: Student Wears KKK Halloween Costume Through 4 Class Periods Before Being Reprimanded
node.description: "We are committed to addressing what has occurred and working with this student to help him recognize the harm his actions have caused," the school's principal said.

node.title: Elementary Class' Field Trip to Bar Prompts Death Threats Toward School Board
node.description: The owner of the bar and grill told local media outlets he too has received "horrible" emails in response to the students' visit.

node.title: North Carolina Parents 'Shocked' by Middle School Art Assignment Depicting a Sexual Act
node.description: "I didn't think I needed to look up what my child was learning in an art class," said one school parent of the art assignment.

node.title: Florida 'Teacher of the Year' Allegedly Hit Student in the Face, Arrested for Child Abuse
node.description: The incident occurred after a student commented on an Instagram post announcing the teacher's award, but the teacher has denied touching the student.

node.title: Teacher Who Came to School in Blackface Forced to Wash to 'Not Cause Further Harm'
node.description: "There must be accountability when racism is exhibited and our children are harmed," an advocacy group said.

node.title: University of Florida Under Review After Refusing to Let 3 Professors Testify in Court
node.description: The school previously said that the testimony would go against the school's interest and relationship with Gov. Ron DeSantis.

node.title: Law School to Remove Name of Founder Who Sponsored Massacres of Native Americans
node.description: The University of California Hastings College of the Law voted to change its name to distance itself from its founder's attacks against Indigenous people

node.title: California College to Allow Homeless Students to Sleep in Their Cars in Secure Garage
node.description: "Our goal at LBCC is always to remove barriers that get in the way of our student's success," interim superintendent of the LBCC District, Dr. Mike Muñoz said.

node.title: 'Party of Parents': GOP to Build on Fight Against Critical Race Theory for Midterms
node.description: Republicans are planning to strengthen their campaigns against diversity-centered academia in the wake of Tuesday's elections.

node.title: Multiple Yale University Buildings Threatened With Bombs
node.description: The threats had targeted at least seven facilities across the Yale campus in New Haven, Connecticut.

node.title: Death Science Says It Had a Contract to Use Vet's Body for Education After Widow's Dispute
node.description: An organization that purchased a cadaver for what it said was educational purposes, used it for public dissection at an event where tickets were sold.

node.title: Internet Calls Woman Out After Eating MIL's Birthday Cake in Viral Post
node.description: The woman told her husband he was overreacting after he was upset that she stole a slice of his mother's birthday cake.

node.title: Weed Helped Man Who Hated Exercise Become Ultra-Marathon Runner
node.description: In his new book "Runner's High," Josiah Hesse delves into the subculture of amateur and elite athletes who use cannabis for exercise.

node.title: Some Pro Sports Teams Nix COVID Vaccinations, Negative Test Requirements For Fans
node.description: The teams include a mix of NHL and NBA clubs from Tennessee to Texas.
